result.execSummary:
The defendant Jacob E Miller was found guilty of the following charge(s) in this case.

  • Strangulation and Suffocation [Modifiers: Repeater], a class H felony, Wisconsin Statutes 940.235(1).
  • Burglary-Building or Dwelling [Modifiers: Repeater], a class F felony, Wisconsin Statutes 943.10(1m)(a).
  • Intimidate Victim/Dissuade Reporting [Modifiers: Repeater], a class A misdemeanor, Wisconsin Statutes 940.44(1).

Charge(s) in this case were read in to this or other case(s). A "read in" charge is a charge that is dismissed as part of a plea agreement, however:

  • The defendant agrees to have the court consider the charge(s) when sentencing for another crime, under Wis. Stats. 973.20(1g)(b); and
  • The defendant cannot be prosecuted for these charge(s) in the future.

Notice to employers: It may be a violation of state law to discriminate against a job applicant because of an arrest or conviction record. Generally speaking, an employer may refuse to hire an applicant on the basis of a conviction only if the circumstances of the conviction substantially relate to the particular job. For more information, see Wisconsin Statute 111.335 and the Department of Workforce Development's publication, Arrest and Conviction Records under the Law.

supervisions.notes: Consecutive to jail time on case nos. 14-CM-39, 15-CM-23.

miscConds.notes: $100 fine plus costs. Pay supervision fees as ordered by Dept. of Corrections. If probation is revoked or discharged with outstanding financial obligations, a civil judgment shall be entered against the defendant in favor of restitution victims and/or governmental entities for the balance due. All available enforcement actions will be used to collect the debt.

timeConds.notes: One month of sentence is stayed to be used at discretion of Court through petition by Dept. of Corrections. Consecutive to case nos. 14-CM-39, 15-CM-23. Huber privileges granted. 4 weeks to report.

All available enforcement actions will be used to collect the debt.

Maintain absolute sobriety from alcohol. Not to possess or consume any controlled substances without a valid prescription and then only take in the amount and frequency prescribed. No contact direct or indirect with victim.
Complete any counseling, evaluations, programs and assessments as appropriate resulting from the Department's COMPAS assessment.
Obtain AODA assessment and comply with treatment recommendations.

records.addlTxt: Granting Defendant's Motion for Postconviction Relief

Defendant Jacob E Miller in court with attorney Mark R Thompson. Defendant Jacob E Miller in custody. Nicholas Grode appeared for the State of Wisconsin. Court reviews filings. State's position has not changed. Court grants two portions of argument. Defense presents argument regarding sentence credit. State presents argument. Defense responds. Court makes statement, grants Defendant's motion in its entirety. Atty Thompson will prepare order. State requests that issue be preserved for appeal.

records.addlTxt: It is ordered that the time for filing a notice of intent is extended to twenty days from the date of this order.
Defendant's Notice and Motion for Leave to File Notice of Intent to Pursue Post-Conviction Relief Pursuant to Wis. Stats. Sec. 809.82 (filed with COA)

No Contact Modification Request. State objects, however Defendant is on probation on this case and "no contact" is ordered as a condition of that and lifting it would require Defendant ask for sentence modification, which Plaintiff would also oppose. Per court, this was a specific condition imposed on Count 4. Defendant would need to file Motion for Modification of Sentence.

records.addlTxt: Defendant Jacob E Miller in court with attorney Brett E Reetz. Defendant Jacob E Miller in custody. Joan M. Korb appeared for the State of Wisconsin. Court reviews charges, max. penalties, elements. Defendant enters no contest pleas to Counts 3, 4, 5. Court questions Defendant on rights, finds pleas made freely and voluntarily, accepts pleas, and finds Defendant guilty of Counts 3, 4, 5. Counts 1, 2, 6 are dismissed but read in for sentencing. Court questions Defendant, who agrees with repeater status. State/Defense make sentencing recommendations. Bond no longer in effect.
